results.title: Loyal tubthumper: Minnie Appleby
results.brief_description: This program is an account of the life of Minnie Appleby (nee Birch) who was born in 1900 and died in 1982. Minnie Appleby’s life story echoes the development of women through this century - she was a suffragette, political speaker, communist activist, housewife, mother, working woman and, later in life, women’s liberationist.

results.title: Loyal to my image
results.creator_credit: Alison Wotherspoon, AFTRS and Harriet McKern
results.brief_description: ‘Loyal to my image’ is a powerful documentary about adoption, mothering and personal identity. Through one woman’s experience as an adopted person and also as a mother who relinquishes her child in 1971, this documentary highlights the many complex issues associated with adoption. By structuring Fae’s adoption experience into seven sections: Fantasy, Loss, Virgin/Whore, Institutions, Searching, Identity and Progress, the issues examined include women as mothers, the politics of reproduction, the laws that implement family policy and the control of personal information in our society. At the completion of Fae’s story the documentary questions who is benefitting from the much proclaimed scientific advances in reproductive technology, when infertility is another disease to be cured. Who decides who has the right to mother and what are the emotional, financial and social costs in human terms?

results.title: Lower strings; Brass; Percussion
results.creator_credit: Jonathan Hewes, Declan Lowney and Initial (GB)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Orchestra!”.
This volume of the “Orchestra!” series examines the role of the lower strings: the cello and the double bass. Examines the effect of the invention of the valve on brass instruments and the role of percussion instruments in the orchestra.

results.title: Low impact technology: solar heating
results.creator_credit: R and R Productions and Ron V. Brown
results.brief_description: Experiments with solar energy have been carried out for many years, especially domestic solar hot water and heating systems. Architects, and scientists from the CSIRO and the University of Melbourne comment on the types and requirements of today’s solar heating systems, and how they can be used domestically and industrially. Photography by John Ruane.

results.title: Low deposit, easy terms
results.brief_description: Sue Ford was one of the first feminist photographers and filmmakers in Australia, initiating her practice during the early 1960s in Melbourne. An active member of many feminist film co-operatives, her works explore Australian identity and feminism, excavating the effects of Australia’s colonial past through playful, innovative and experimental films. In Low Deposit Easy Terms, Ford interrogates Australia’s obsession with car culture, but instead of open Outback roads, the viewer tours inner-city car dealerships, home garages and junkyards where life struggles to grow.

constellations_other.name: Alternate histories and futures
constellations_other.description: Sue Ford's Egami reimagines contemporary life through a feminist and colonial lens.

results.title: Loving parents
results.creator_credit: Texture Films and Herman J. Engel
results.brief_description: This sex education film is designed for parents but its style and content is very appealing to young people also. Brief “trigger” sequences are used to raise the kinds of questions which concern most mothers and fathers.

results.title: Loving our bottle
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, David Withers and ACMI
results.brief_description: ‘The Bottle’ in Rutherglen is a landmark that everyone in town has a connection to. Originally used as the town’s water tower, an iron mesh addition transformed it into the wine bottle of Rutherglen, a beacon by which locals find their way home.
